title: 103_hr3464
content:
The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" authorizes funds for the modernization of the Modular Airborne Fire Fighting System. The Forest Service will study ways to improve airborne fire fighting response time and report to Congress within a year. Increased criminal penalties for arsonists are also included in the Act. The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" increases penalties for malicious use of fire or explosives on federal property, with fines or imprisonment up to 10 years. Circumstances like damage exceeding $1,000,000 result in fines and imprisonment of 5 to 20 years. If the damage caused by the offense exceeds $1,000,000, the offender faces a fine and imprisonment of 5 to 20 years. If the offense results in jeopardy to a person's life or damage over $10,000,000, the penalty is a fine and imprisonment of 8 to 30 years. In cases of personal injury or damage exceeding $25,000,000, the offender can be fined and imprisoned for 10 to 40 years. If the offense results in the death of a person, the offender faces severe consequences. If personal injury results or damage exceeds $25,000,000, the offender faces a fine and imprisonment of 10 to 40 years. In cases of death, the offender may face a fine, imprisonment exceeding 25 years, or even the death penalty. The punishment for offenses related to interstate commerce under section 844 of title 18, United States Code, includes fines and imprisonment ranging from 5 to 20 years based on the extent of damage caused. If the damage exceeds $1,000,000, the offender faces a fine and imprisonment for not less than 5 nor more than 20 years. If the damage caused by the offense exceeds $1,000,000, the offender will face a fine and imprisonment for not less than 5 nor more than 20 years. If the life of any person is endangered or the damage exceeds $10,000,000, the punishment increases to a fine and imprisonment for not less than 8 nor more than 30 years. If personal injury occurs or the damage exceeds $25,000,000, the offender will be fined and imprisoned for not less than 10 nor more than 40 years. If personal injury results to any person or the damage caused by the offense exceeds $25,000,000, the offender shall be subject to a fine and imprisoned for not less than 10 nor more than 40 years. If the death of any person results, the offender shall be subject to a fine and imprisoned for any term of years greater than 25, and also be subject to the death penalty. The amendment to Section 844 of title 18, United States Code, introduces penalties for reckless conduct resulting in destruction of property or injury to others, with fines or imprisonment up to one year. If no imprisonment is imposed, probation with community service is required. The amendment to Section 844 of title 18, United States Code, introduces penalties for reckless conduct resulting in destruction of property or injury to others. Offenders may face fines, imprisonment up to one year, or probation with community service. Juveniles adjudicated for similar offenses must also serve time in a residential institution and perform community service. The amendment to Section 844 of title 18, United States Code, introduces penalties for reckless conduct resulting in destruction of property or injury to others. Offenders may face fines, imprisonment up to one month, or probation with community service. Juveniles adjudicated for similar offenses must also serve time in a residential institution and perform community service. The Forest Service will study federal legal barriers to clearing fire hazards and report to Congress within a year. Defense conversion will enhance private firefighting capabilities. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Federal Aviation Administration, will report to Congress on utilizing excess military cargo and private fire fighting contractors for fire fighting purposes. Additionally, they will explore reforming Federal aviation regulations to maximize the use of planes for fire fighting. SEC. 7. The Forest Service will study building roads and backup power supplies to ensure water availability for fire fighting in national forest areas. Results will be reported to Congress within a year.

SEC. 8. The Secretary of Agriculture will reduce below-cost direct loans of the Farmers Home Administration by 5% for fiscal years 1994 through 1998.
